summary: In 1962, journalist Chow Mo-wan (Tony Leung Chiu Wai) and his wife move into a Hong Kong apartment, but Chow's spouse is often away on business. Before long, the lonely Chow makes the acquaintance of the alluring Su Li-zhen (Maggie Cheung Man-yuk), whose own significant other also seems preoccupied with work. As the two friends realize their respective partners are cheating on them, they begin to fall for one another; however, neither wants to stoop to the level of the unfaithful spouses.

An absolute masterpiece. A sumptuous feast for the eyes, and a turbulent, searing voyage for the heart. The premise is interesting, the setting is palpable, the characters are masterfully presented (or not presented as the case may be), the pace is precisely the right speed. The score is excellent and the main original song is catchy and well-matched to the drama, as well as a couple of other songs noticeably matched perfectly to the scene. You will find yourself immediately in the hands of a master, and you'll wonder how all cinema is not like this. Wong Kar-Wai uses a color pallete and close, intimate shots to do much of the work of setting the tone and feel of the film, which is a profound longing amid a kind of despair at being betrayed. 

*Spoilers*: In a masterful coda before a final ruminatory scene at Angkor Wat Temple, we see the subsequent visits to the apartment building in Hong Kong years later.  Mrs. Chan is shown 
as a single mother with a son, suggesting at least to this viewer that the love affair and offstage final night spent together between her and Mr. Chow was a sexual encounter that resulted in a pregnancy. Later when Mr. Chow shows up to check on the apartment and discovers that "a woman" who he suspects is Mrs. Chan is living alone with their child (we have seen her seeming happier--though still longing--wearing her hair down and wearing a less formal dress than we have seen before in the film), which he never knew existed. He smiles and pauses at her door on the way out as if thinking about knocking, but decides to leave them alone. Their friendship and strange secret--but pure--romance created life. Likewise in the final scenes at the Angkor Wat Temple in Cambodia, we see that Mr. Chow's secrets are being whispered into a gouge of rock and covers it with mud to keep it safe forever, per the old folktale of the region. A few frames later we see that a snarl of grass is growing where he covered his secret with mud, alive against all odds. This is partly a reflection of how a secret, like the secret friendship with Mrs. Chan and their secret rehearsals and conversations, can be healing and life-giving.

Wong reinvents Romanticism.
The delicacy with which he depicts the subdued emotions of the two protagonists gives life to a poetic romance that sublimates the idea of love.
"In the Mood for Love", despite the long gestation period of almost two years, is less dynamic and confused than Wong's previous works, but has a more solid narrative and a more disciplined mise-en-sc√®ne.
With epiphanic enthusiasm, the camera slides slowly through the corridors, peers voyeuristically by the mirrors, moves sensual between the curtains; contemplating the inexorable passage of time.
It is precisely in the circularity of time that Wong's seventh effort finds its balance. Time that reveals itself repeatedly throughout the film: literally with the continuous insert shots of clocks and cigarettes, abstractly with the weightless slow motions and the evanescent motion blur of Doyle's cinematography.
Chow and Su's tormented mel√≤ collapses when they realize what they feel about each other. So, they flee, perhaps because basically it is always the ideal of love that the two protagonists are in love with. The metaphysical vision of love, uncontaminated and intimist, which in the incompleteness of their desires remains forever suspended in time, ethereal and immortal.
"In the Mood for Love" is made up of hesitant glances and suppressed caresses, in a turbid whirl of regret and passion.
It is a love story that never blossoms, but basks in its indecision, forced to remain a secret buried for millenniums in the prison of one's heart.
Without a doubt, Wong's highest aesthetic and narrative achievement and one of the best films of the 21st century.

This is a delicate film, as if "love" itself was a brittle piece of Venetian glass. Su Li-zhen (Maggie Cheung) and Chow Mo-wan (Tony Leung) have a couple of things in common: they live adjacent to each other in the same apartment (kind of like a rooming house?) building and their spouses are cheating on them with each other. The plot follows Su and Chow as they grow from a platonic friendship ‚Äî which feels more out of necessity, to ward off loneliness ‚Äî to something more. The surroundings are tight ‚Äî cramped hallways, small bedrooms, alleyways filled with customers and workers, it is Hong Kong, after all. Our protags are subdued, polite, and you want them to get nice and good and mad. Other than a couple of moments of unrestricted painful emotion, Su and Chow take their spouses' infidelity on the chin. The timing isn't right for them because it can't be right for them, it wouldn't make as touching a movie. Their style is defined by early 1960s glory. The recurring slow-motion shots ‚Äî including the notable "Corridor Glance" ‚Äî set to "Yumeji's Theme" highlight the runtime, which is shot on film and it shows. I'd known about the sentimental final sequence, as it's rightfully lauded, and wasn't disappointed as it appeared before me. Simply, it's gorgeous. Wong Kar-wai's In the Mood for Love is a must-see for cinephiles, and while it may be too slow or not exciting enough for a general audience, I'd recommend anyone give it a try.

When Chow Mo-wan realizes that his wife is having an affair with the next-door neighbor, he develops a tightly knit relationship with the neighbor's wife, Su Li-zhen.  Despite the fact that romance begins to blossom between the two, they manage to repress their feelings in an effort to not lower themselves to the level of their unfaithful spouses.  In the Mood for Love is a story of a mutually agreed upon unrequited love, beautifully shot with a rich color palette, beautifully written and subtly acted, where the actors express more through stolen glances and gentle touches than they do through dialogue.  The emotions explored are heart-breaking and the feelings evoked are unforgettable.

The characters set against the drabness and claustrophobia of 60s Hong Kong positively shine, the women in their snazzy figure-hugging floral outfits. There is clearly sex in the air, but it is all off-screen.
The Director even makes us feel like pepping-Toms catching the characters through the windows, framed in the tiny rooms that act as cages, helpless as they are as life and other impulses mark their fate.
Not only visually arresting, but a wonderful use of music, make sure you watch this film in a theatre with a good sound-system or invest in a top-notch home cinema, or you won't get to enjoy the aural atmospherics of Nat King Cole serenading you and setting the tone for what is unfolding so seductively.

It's pretty deflating when you see a film with so many accolades, plaudits and gushing reviews, only to feel completely let down by it. In The Mood For Love was ranked, in 1 poll, as the 2nd greatest film of the 21st century, an assessment which, I have to say, I'm dumbfounded by. The film goes for a minimalistic quality, especially in regard to the dialogue. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, in fact it's quiet refreshing. Most of the emotions are conveyed through camerawork and facial expressions, with no need for lengthy explanations. The faces of the unfaithful spouses are never shown, because the film is not about them. The focus is on the bond which develops between their partners, and its resulting consequences. I enjoyed the movie at first, but soon the real lack of any substance starts to wear thin, and before the 3rd act had begun, I'd already mentally checked out. The film has so much dead air, so much wasted time where nothing happens, but feels the need to linger, because that's what audiences want to see apparently. The slow, quiet moments didn't feel like they were there to let emotions register or feelings develop, it felt like the film just didn't have anything interesting to say. It's sensitively acted by it's leads, which is to say they look mildly annoyed and cry occasionally. It starts with promises but falls flat by the last frame. I wouldn't see it again, and unless somebody had absolutely nothing else to do for an hour and a half, I wouldn't recommend it to anyone either.

I don't have a keen enough eye for artistry to have appreciated this as much as everyone else appears to have. I did notice the excellent color palette and set/costume designs as they made a very visually pleasing experience for me, Bulbazard, the enemy of desaturation. The main impression I got from this was that Wong heard someone say that it's impossible/very difficult to shoot a movie in a location as cramped as a real-life apartment complex with its narrow hallways and no room for good camera placement and opted to make this movie to show like 35 different ways to do it, shooting from angles like underneath the clothes in a closet or through a peephole or from an open doorway in the hall or from on top of the fridge in the kitchen. I didn't find the story itself particularly believable as it would be nonsensical for either main character to assume they would carry on a years-long close relationship without either catching feelings for the other. The notion that either would have really stayed with their spouses for years during/after their respective affairs, particularly with an obviously superior choice of life partner sitting right next to them didn't seem logical to me whatsoever and I don't think cultural differences fully explain that. The actors were excellent, but the dialogue wasn't creative/interesting enough to make this a superior movie to 2001's Amelie.

First I will tell you my perspective such that you can decide how well you relate to it and can rely on it in determining how much you might like the film.  I watch virtually every film that becomes available to me, including mainstream and at the local art house.  When it comes to foreign films and art movies, I wouldn't say they are uniquely my jam, but I don't shy away from them either, and like them at about the same rate that I would like anything that comes out at the mainstream theater.

I certainly recognized the technical virtuosity and artistic sensibilities brought to bear on this film.  It was haunting, and at times in grossing, and I don't think anyone could ever claim that the acting was anything less than excellent.  

That said, it can be slow, obscure, and abrupt in a variety of ways, and for that reason, it demands a lot of the viewer over the course of its runtime.  I was on board for that journey throughout, but did expect more pay off than ended up being there.  

(vague semi-spoilers follow)

I suppose it is possible that this ended up being revealed in a way that was subtle enough that I missed it, but so far as I can tell, it was not really explained how either of the two marriages involved proceeded from the events of the core of the film. That is to say, the ending was fairly vague, and I'm not afraid to admit that I found the last handful of scenes collectively rather confusing.  not that I don't get the general gist of how the romance at the core of the movie ended up, but I guess I'm not sure in much detail how the lives of those characters proceeded, nor even why they made the decisions they made or how they felt about those decisions- especially Mrs. Chan.  And again, it's possible I just missed it, but I also happen to have absolutely no clue what happened to Mrs. Chow or the Chow marriage.  I was also confused as to what Cambodia in particular had to do with anything or why Chow went there, aside from providing some nice scenery for the closing sequence, and was especially unclear as to why it was so important to the story that the location deserved its own introductory archival footage right at the end of the film.

I just genuinely found the overall effect to be pretty frustrating and a bit confusing, and you'll have to take my word for it that I'm no dunce in film interpretation generally-speaking, even if it turns out that I botched this one.

This is everything that 2046 was not. A beautifully told, lavish yet restrained, story of unrequited (or just unconsummated?) love, with enough time given to the characters for you to actually care about them. Tons of great directorial moves, too (never showing the spouses faces etc.). Beautifully filmed with a beautiful score, too. I found this film touching and satisfying, despite the heartache.

A fresh take on the classic "boy meets girl" love story. In the Mood for Love stands out for its striking costumes, moving score, and crisp cinematography. Every frame in this movie looks like it could be a portrait. It's also incredibly understated. There are no sweeping romantic gestures or "holding boomboxes outside your house" moments. Perhaps, that's why it didn't resonate as thoroughly emotionally as I wanted.

This is an elegant, subtly intense, economical meditation on fidelity and the price that sacrifice can mean. More specifically, it's about fidelity in the face of great loneliness and likely infidelity, with the very real presence of another person there who could give you respite from such sadness and uncertainty. We all have the need to feel wanted, loved, appreciated. When we have that, we feel so close to complete, with the security and assurance it brings. The film is gorgeous to look at. The colors and the look of the characters, from hair styles to wardrobe choices, gives a real sense of 60's films. There's even a touch or two of new-wave Euro movies of that era. Great choices were made throughout by Kar-Wai Wong. The subtleties of glances, quiet but telling body language, saying so much in silence, and those tight shots of Su Li-zhen exuding femininity as she walks up those stairs show the signs of a mature director who knows the power of the visual image and how it can say as much as a shot/scene filled with dialogue. 
Excellent work also by leads Tony Leung Chiu Wai and Maggie Cheung Man-yuk. 
I think of the scene where Chow and Su are first sitting in his apt./room, with the camera set as if under a table or through a keyhole, with us as voyeurs into their new secret friendship, which hints at being more. And then the crushing reminder of history at the very end, along with a secret whispered into a stone wall that makes up part of the halls of a structure constructed for mankind to ponder the mysteries of life, to help resolve our questions and searching, and to reach the peace of mind, security and happiness with our place in the world that the love of a faithful other can bring us. 3.7 stars
